review.title: An Action Language for Multi-Agent Domains: Foundations
review.abstract: In multi-agent domains (MADs), an agent's action may not just change the world and the agent's knowledge and beliefs about the world, but also may change other agents' knowledge and beliefs about the world and their knowledge and beliefs about other agents' knowledge and beliefs about the world. The goals of an agent in a multi-agent world may involve manipulating the knowledge and beliefs of other agents' and again, not just their knowledge/belief about the world, but also their knowledge about other agents' knowledge about the world. Our goal is to present an action language (mA+) that has the necessary features to address the above aspects in representing and RAC in MADs. mA+ allows the representation of and reasoning about different types of actions that an agent can perform in a domain where many other agents might be present---such as world-altering actions, sensing actions, and announcement/communication actions. It also allows the specification of agents' dynamic awareness of action occurrences which has future implications on what agents' know about the world and other agents' knowledge about the world. mA+ considers three different types of awareness: full,- partial- awareness, and complete oblivion of an action occurrence and its effects. This keeps the language simple, yet powerful enough to address a large variety of knowledge manipulation scenarios in MADs. The semantics of mA+ relies on the notion of state, which is described by a pointed Kripke model and is used to encode the agent's knowledge and the real state of the world. It is defined by a transition function that maps pairs of actions and states into sets of states. We illustrate properties of the action theories, including properties that guarantee finiteness of the set of initial states and their practical implementability. Finally, we relate mA+ to other related formalisms that contribute to RAC in MADs.

metadata.title: An Action Language for Multi-Agent Domains: Foundations

sections.text: The aim of this paper is to present an action language called mA +, which has the necessary characteristics to address the above aspects in the representation and reasoning of actions and changes in multi-agent domains. This action language can be considered as a generalization of the action languages of individual actors extensively studied in the literature, up to multi-agent domains. The action language also allows the representation and reflection of different types of actions that an actor can perform in an area where many other actors could be present - such as world-changing actions, sentient actions and announcement / communication actions. The action language also allows the specification of the dynamic consciousness of action events that have future effects on the knowledge of actors about the world and the knowledge of other actors about the world. The language map mA + looks at three different types of consciousness: complete awareness, partial awareness and complete forgetting of an action area and its effects.

sections.heading: 1.2 Paper Organization
sections.text: The rest of the paper is broken down as follows: Section 2 describes the basic definitions and notation of a modal logic with faith operators and the update model-based approach to arguing actions in multi-agent domains. This section also describes a series of operators to kripke structures used in defining the semantics of mA +. Section 3 presents the syntax of mA +. Section 4 defines the transition function of mA +, which maps pairs of actions and states into states; the section also presents the entanglement relationship between mA + action theories and queries. Section 5 examines the modelling of mA + semantics using the update model approach. Section 6 identifies a class of mA + theories whose initial states can be clearly characterized and effectively calculated. Section 7 provides an analysis of mA + with respect to existing literature, including a comparison with DEL.

sections.heading: 3.1 Actions and effects
sections.text: We assume that each action can be performed in exactly one of the three categories: world-changing actions (also known as ontic actions), sensory actions, and announcement actions. Intuitively, a world-changing action is used to explicitly modify certain characteristics of the world - for example, Agent A opens the field in Example 1, or Agent A distracts Agent B so that B does not look at the field (also in Example 1); • a sensitizing action is used by an agent to disprove his views of the world by making direct observations - for example, an agent looks into the field; the effect of the sensitizing action is to reduce the uncertainty of the agent; • an announcement action is used by an agent to influence the beliefs of the agents who receive the communication - we operate under the assumption that agents who receive an announcement always believe what is announced. For simplicity reasons, we assume that each action is one of the three categories.

sections.heading: 7.3 Previous Work by the Authors
sections.text: Early attempts to adapt action languages to formalize multi-agent domains can be found in [42, 43, 44]. In this work, the action languages A, B, and C have been expanded to formalize multi-agent domains. Work in [43, 44] examines the use of action languages in the context of multi-agent planning and focuses on generating decentralized plans for multi-agent domains to achieve either a common goal or individual goals. In [42] we show that several examples found in the literature to address a specific aspect in multi-agent systems (e.g. [45, 46, 47, 48, 49, 50]) can be formalized by extending the action language C. However, most of the extensions considered in [42, 43, 44] are insufficient for formalizing multi-agent domain systems where considerations about the knowledge of other actors are critical. To address this shortcoming, we have developed several preliminary versions of A + 51, 53, and [53].

sections.heading: 8 Conclusions and Future Works
sections.text: In this paper, we developed a language of action for the presentation and argumentation of the effects of actions in multi-agent domains. Language takes into account world-changing actions, scanning actions and announcement actions, and also allows for the dynamic specification of the observability of actors in terms of the occurrence of actions, enabling varying degrees of visibility of action events and action effects. Semantics of language is based on the notion of states (pointed Kripke structures), which are used as representations of the states of the world and states of knowledge and beliefs of actors; semantics is based on a transitional function that maps pairs of states and actions to state states.We discussed several properties of the transitional function and identified a class of theories (defined action theories) whose set of initial S5 states is finite, thus the development of algorithms for the S5 withdrawal relationship, which is crucial in applications of crucial planning and time reasoning.
